page.title: 05THE TILLINGHAM AND THE BREDE
page.content: The two rivers which form our northern and southern boundaries are the Tillingham and the Brede. Both rivers are small and sluggish. The Tilling_ ham is really shallow and would not support a boat of any sort for most of its length through Udimore; the Brede would support a small rowing bioat, being about four feet deep at most. But well within living memory coal barges came regularly up as far as Brede Bridge. And up to the end of the last century quite big boats could sail u p the Tillingham. A mere l50 years ago both valleys were inlets of the sea and as such were ideal haunts for smugglers. Both valleys still flood after prolonged rain, but many fields now have land_drains which clear the water quite quickly.
